tier.item: I would like to thank professors Ted Fernald and Shizhe Huang for their help at all stages of writing this thesis.
Thanks also go to Pen-Pen Chen, who provided her native speaker's intuition for the Mandarin data, and to the
Bryn Mawr College dean's office for reimbursing Pen-Pen for the time she spent working with me.
Where semantically predicative means [having] the capacity to constrain the number meaning and overt
expression of the arguments in the clause"(Mohanan (1997), Bender 455).

tier.item: (16) a. Sie will das Papier zerreissen.
Where `3SgPT' refers to the third person singular present tense ending. The second position in the German
sentence takes the finite, thus [+tense] verb.
"She wants to tear the paper (into many pieces)."
(16) a. Sie will das Papier zerreissen.
Where `3SgPT' refers to the third person singular present tense ending. The second position in the German
sentence takes the finite, thus [+tense] verb.
"She wants to tear the paper (into many pieces)."
Where `3SgPT' refers to the third person singular present tense ending. The second position in the German
sentence takes the finite, thus [+tense] verb.
She wants to tear the paper (into many pieces).
b. Sie will das Papier durchreissen.
"She wants to tear the paper (into two pieces).
b. Sie will das Papier durchreissen.
"She wants to tear the paper (into two pieces).
She wants to tear the paper (into two pieces).
